image.caption: Collection of the U.S. House of Representatives, Gift of Jim Oliver

profileText: A Representative from Ohio; born in Shoreham, Vt., June 4, 1809; moved with his parents to Mount Vernon, Knox County, Ohio, in 1817; pursued an academic course; studied law; was admitted to the bar in 1831 and commenced practice in Mount Vernon; elected as a Whig to the Twenty-ninth Congress (March 4, 1845-March 3, 1847); was not a candidate for renomination in 1846; unsuccessful candidate for the nomination for Governor at the Whig State convention in 1847; delegate to the Republican National Convention in 1860 and 1864; served as State commissary general of Ohio in 1861; unsuccessful candidate by two votes for the United States Senate in 1862; member of the State house of representatives in 1863; elected as a Republican to the Thirty-ninth Congress (March 4, 1865-March 3, 1867); chairman, Committee on Claims (Thirty-ninth Congress); successfully contested the election of George W. Morgan to the Fortieth Congress and served from June 3, 1868, to March 3, 1869; was not a candidate for renomination in 1868; Commissioner of Internal Revenue from March 11, 1869, to October 31, 1870; appointed Secretary of the Interior by President Grant on November 1, 1870, which position he held until October 19, 1875, when he resigned; retired to his farm near Mount Vernon, Ohio; president of the First National Bank of Mount Vernon until his death in Mount Vernon, Ohio, October 23, 1896; interment in Mount View Cemetery.

note.content: Successfully contested the election of George W. Morgan, and took his seat June 3, 1868.
Election unsuccessfully contested by Charles Follett.

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: ------. Remarks of Hon. Columbus Delano of Ohio on rebel war claims: Delivered in the House of Representatives, January 30, 1866. Washington: Congressional Globe Office, 1866.
------. Speech of Hon. Columbus Delano of Ohio on the Civil Rights Bill: Delivered in the House of Representatives, March 8, 1866. Washington: Congressional Globe Office, 1866.
------. Speech of Mr. Columbus Delano, of Ohio, on the Oregon question. Delivered in the House of Representatives, U.S., February 5, 1846. [N.p., n.d.]
Delano, Columbus. Address of Columbus Delano. Washington, D.C.: R. O. Polkinhorn, printer, 1883.
------. Speech of Hon. Columbus Delano, delivered at Raleigh, North Carolina, July 24, 1872. [Raleigh?: N.p., 1872].
------. Speech of Mr. Columbus Delano, of Ohio, against the bill declaring that "a state of war exists by the act of the republic of Mexico." [Washington]: J. & G.S. Gideon, printers, [1846].

------. Speech of Hon. Columbus Delano, of Ohio, on the political condition of the states lately in rebellion; delivered in the House of Representatives, February 10, 1866. Washington: Printed at the Congressional Globe Office, 1866.
------. The tariff: Speech of Hon. C. Delano of Ohio in the House of Representatives, July 10, 1866. Washington: Congressional Globe Office, 1866.

researchRecord.name: In the Hamilton Fish Papers, 1732-1914, 85 linear feet.
researchRecord.description: Correspondents include Columbus Delano. A finding aid is available in the library.

researchRecord.name: In Columbus Delano Family Papers, 1845-1889, 1.2 linear feet.
researchRecord.description: Correspondence (largely 1869) and photograph album relating to Ohio and national politics and patronage, the Republican Party, western lands, railroad expansion, and personal and financial matters. Includes letters concerning the purchase of the archives of the Confederate States of America.

researchRecord.name: In the Ulysses S. Grant Papers, 1843-1969, 100 linear feet.
researchRecord.description: Correspondents include Columbus Delano. A finding aid is available in the library.

researchRecord.name: In the Joshua R. Giddings Papers, 1821-1866, 2.5 cubic feet.
researchRecord.description: Other authors include Columbus Delano. A finding aid is available in the library.

researchRecord.name: 1871-1874, 1 microfilm reel.
researchRecord.description: Microfilmed copy of handwritten letterpress copybooks. The items were sent and received by Columbus Delano and his office. The materials deal with the affairs of his office, Indian relations, and land development in the United States.

researchRecord.name: In the Enoch Hoag Indian Papers, 1865-1883, approximately 668 items.
researchRecord.description: Correspondents include Columbus Delano. A finding aid is available in the repository.

researchRecord.name: 1873, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from Ulysses S. Grant to the Hon. C. Delano, Secretary of the Interior, written on July 25, 1873. In the letter, Ulysses Grant suggests the replacement of Dr. M.K. Hogan by Dr. Phelps to the "Examining Surgeons" of New York. Dr. Phelps is vouched for by General Robinson, a retired officer of the regular Army, now Lt. Govr. of New York.

researchRecord.name: In the Joseph Vance Papers, 1808-1838, 1 cubic foot.
1869-1873. 5 volumes.
researchRecord.description: Letter books documenting his career and material on Indian affairs.

researchRecord.name: In the Philemon Beecher Ewing Papers, 1820-1906, 1.5 cubic feet.
1871-1874, 2 volumes.
researchRecord.description: Columbus Delano's "private" letters written while he was U.S. Secretary of the Interior, dealing especially with Indian affairs. Major recipients include William W. Belknap, James G. Blaine, Simon Cameron, Jay Cooke, Benjamin R. Cowen, Hamilton Fish, Ulysses S. Grant, Hannibal Hamlin, James Harlan, Rutherford B. Hayes, Timothy O. Howe, Robert C. Schenck, William T. Sherman, and Henry Whipple. .

researchRecord.name: 1873, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from Columbus Delano to William W. Belknap written on November 17, 1873. In the letter, Columbus Delano makes an appointment to discuss Indian affairs.

recordLocation.name: Department of Literary and Historical Manuscripts

researchRecord.name: In the James Family Papers, 1850-1904, 2 cubic feet.
1867, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from Joseph Pomeroy Buckland to President Andrew Johnson written on February 7, 1867. In the letter, Joseph Buckland recommends Cooper K. Watson for District Attorney of the Northern District of Ohio. The letter is also signed by Reps. Delano, Hubbell, Welker, Lawrence, Eckley, and Bingham.

recordLocation.name: Department of Literary and Historical Manuscripts

researchRecord.name: ca. 1871-1896, 1 microfilm reel.
researchRecord.description: Letterpress copies of Delano's "private" letters written while he was U.S. Secretary of the Interior, dealing especially with Indian affairs. Major recipients include William W. Belknap, James G. Blaine, Simon Cameron, Jay Cooke, Benjamin R. Cowen, Hamilton Fish, Ulysses S. Grant, Hannibal Hamlin, James Harlan, Rutherford B. Hayes, Timothy O. Howe, Robert C. Schenck, William T. Sherman, and Henry Whipple. Originals are at the Ohio Historical Society.

researchRecord.name: In the Benjamin R. Cowen Papers, 1846-1897, 52 items.
1834-1839, 4 items.
researchRecord.description: Letter, 1834, from Columbus Delano to his future mother-in-law asking permission to marry her daughter, and correspondence, 1836-1839, between Delano, away on business, and his wife at home at Mount Vernon, Ohio, including a letter describing Philadelphia.

researchRecord.name: In the Maria D. Coffinberry Family Papers, 1767-1930, 1.2 linear feet.
In the John H. Klippart Papers, 1833-1933, 13 cubic feet.
